title: Outlook... I never thought...
text: I never thought I’d congratulate Devs of a Microsoft product on an iOS device, but, well done folks. There are some specifics that irritate me; however, on the whole, the app works seamlessly with all my email addresses (personal and professional). I’m very happy to have a stable app that I can rely upon for my Apple devices, and hope to see more improvements and bug fixes in the future. As it is now, new options become available from time to time that seem to address many of my issues, which makes Outlook better and better, and my ‘go to’ email app.

title: You Cost Me the Best Employer of All Time, Outlook
text: Outlook, you have just ruined the best follow-up, touch-bases-in-2-years email that I have ever made to a global, innovative company that I have ever encountered in the last 21 years by you constantly reloading my Outlook screens with your unneeded, interruptive daily, every-other-hourly so-called “updates” while I use my application. For this yet another interruption, instead of saving my lengthy but amazing draft, your screen prompted the Delete/Discard Draft button to where my finger was on top of Save Draft. For this, I can no longer forgive you, Outlook. It is true that you sent the best versions of my resumes and other documents, but the September 12, 2017 update ruined my Outlook application for good. For this, I can no longer let this slide, I can no longer forgive you, Outlook. You cost me the best employer that I have ever encountered in the last 21 years since 1996.

title: The search functionality is really an issue
text: You guys have came long ways but still need solid work on search I am almost sure  not to find an attachment or old email even sometime would go back to that date but seems like if someone replied to an email or it is in sent, it gets excluded from search. I see the the same problem with browser based app as opposed to the old stand-alone MS Outlook program that used to have solid search functionality. Is it related to threads? You should make it easier and more intuitive to search. Simple things like finding email by sender would be a great help.

title: Great app. Works just like desktop
text:
I absolutely love this app. It works great with my iPhone. Almost everything works perfectly. Sometimes it works better than a desktop version (old laptop). Scheduling appointments is a breeze and the calendar alerts, auto time zones, etc. are fantastic. 

Sometimes when I cancel an appointment on my iCloud calendar, it doesn’t sync to my Outlook. That’s probably user error but that’s the only thing that I notice that gets frustrating. This is only occasionally. I remember to use the app for all my Calendar stuff and then I never have a problem.

title: What a mail app should be
text:
After having used this app for all of ten minutes, I switched from the default mail app. I have 4 accounts (2 Exchange and 2 personal), and Apple’s one size fits all model is beginning to wear thin. New features are being added frequently (not once a year with an ios update), support is excellent, and functionality is oh so fluid. 

Favorite features so far: customizable swipe, dynamic calendar layout, security options like Touch ID, integration with one drive. 

I love Apple hardware, but their lowest common denominator approach to software is no longer the only option in town, and that’s great news for everyone.

title: I hate this app…
text:
Why for the love of god would you ever take away the ability to mark emails as complete? I can’t even revert to an older version of Outlook like I can, on my Mac. So, I’m being forced to use this lesser IOS version of Outlook, that takes away the last differentiating, useful feature away. I seriously doubt that Microsoft would ever dare do the same thing to PC/Android users—you would never take away their ability to to do something as basic as complete email flags.

(I might as well use my IOS native mail app because at least with that, I can move emails to folders under different accounts.)

The “New Outlook” on the Mac is terrible because of so many reasons, but the main reason being that you can no longer mark messages complete; but at least on my Mac (for now) I can toggle off the new version.

I don’t know what’s wrong with Microsoft, but I’m struggling to justify keeping my Office 365 subscription at all; because your Mac/IOS version apps are nowhere near as useful as the PC versions. Why even bother? I can’t even wrap my head around your decision making and it’s infuriating. And to top it all off, you’re touting this as some great improvement. It’s disgusting and tone deaf—a complete miss.

title: And the rotten-app games continue courtesy of the big-baby org Microsoft
text:
Dangerously incorrigible app behavior.

This device already has a default browser configured, Microsoft.  Use it or this app gets gone.  I am not using your new browser and i hope i never need to.

Need to copy/paste/tweak text?  Get ready to struggle when you don’t want to struggle.  [for example] Microsoft:  Stop trying to auto finish email addresses and let the human being user alone to do it for themself.  You get it wrong every time and no user wants to deal with risky app behaviors, even when their from Microsoft.  Especially when they’re from Microsoft.  And even more especially when we need to send / receive emails. But these awful app behaviors are alive and well and Microsoft doesn’t care.  And they will cost you time nearly every time.

Stop masquerading your advertisements as emails in my ‘Inbox’ list view.  It is neither the time nor the place for your stupid ads and it never will be, Microsoft,  Get them gone forever or this app gets gone.

And you did steal the WIndows UX from Apple for $1 a bunch of years ago.  And maybe i will need Office 365 for iPad and maybe I wont, but this is not the way to win over more people to do it.

title: Not good if you have multiple emails.
text:
I installed this app because I wanted a different approach from Gmail and the original Mail app on my device. And I’m not going to lie, the interface is great. However, it seems as if you can only add one account from another email service that isn’t Microsoft.

Take this for example. I have 3-4 other different Microsoft accounts (for reasons i’m not going to get into) and they all were able to easily get set up and right in to outlook. However, when I tried to add my google accounts, while thinking I was successful because I added one, I realized I could only add one single email.

Whenever I tried to add my other two email accounts from Google, I failed miserably. It just kept loading and loading almost as it was redirecting me, but it never did. Meaning that I was stuck in this endless redirecting loop until it said that an error occurred or until I closed out.

This app is great if you have only one email. Just one. Unless you’re planning to merge your gmail accounts, STAY AWAY FROM THIS APP. Use the regular G-Mail instead.

title: Awesome email client
text:
MS Outlook for Mac and iPhone works great. I am very comfortable with it in a corporate setting, but to use it for my small business, I am missing a few features. 
First off and most troublesome is the lack of a synching calendar. I can only use my calendar on my MacBook and not my phone which makes it impossible to rely on for appointments and reminders. Secondly, the ability to sort by sender or topic (from right-click) seems to be missing, too. Not sure if these are corporate only or not. I guess, I will have to get a third party web-based calendar and synchronized it to Outlook. Extra work I didn’t want. Good things are Outlook is a great organizer. Easy to use for email and a nice clean interface.

title: I don’t know how anyone else is using this
text:
Update 1/1/21: still buggy and it has also has created countless duplicate contact entries for each person that I now have to consolidate. The apps to do this cause other problems so it will be a semi manual process for me. I have thousands of contacts. This client also does not have a decent search function. It fails to search all my emails and/or never finds any matching my criteria. When I go to the native email client, they pop right up. Deleting the app

——————
Previous review: It’s buggy and basically unusable on IOS. Maybe they are using the computer version.  On both my 12.9” iPAD and my iPhone XR the app keeps automatically kicking me out of the email when I’m replying saves the draft. This happens in the middle of a sentence. I thought at first that I was accidentally hitting something as I typed to make this happen, but no it happens even if I type really slowly and carefully. I literally end up having ten drafts in my drafts folder from the app spontaneously doing this. The only way for me to reply is by using the Desktop software (which has problems of its own.. like not being able to edit addresses in the contacts panel - look it up - that’s not supported). 

I will be going back to Spark.

title: Really good - far superior to default email
text: Let me start by explaining the reason why I see it superior to default iPhone email. Surprisingly Microsoft beat apple in making the experience smoother. Simple things like attaching a pic or a document, with this app, there is a clear easy to click attachment button and it even simplify things further by giving u option of attaching “Last photo taken” which is quite handy instead of navigating to the right pic or screen shot you just took. Default apple requires, long click, scroll two times , then select add attachment 😩

title: Email great, calendar not so much
text: I use Outlook for work, but have yet to fully use the calendar because the calendar and email are within the same app. That might seem like an advantage, but when I’m sent an email asking, “Are you available on Tuesday at 10?” I cannot toggle between the calendar and email function seamlessly. I would way rather have the calendar as a stand-alone app so I could toggle back and forth when trying to schedule things on my phone. If the calendar were it’s own app, I could look at my calendar with one tap, rather than opening mail and then switching to the calendar view.

title: Good overall, but the search tool stinks
text: I’ve used this app for a almost 5 years now as my college used Outlook based email as does my job. I’ve seen a number of improvements to the app and I’d definitely recommend it, I especially like the easy swipe functionality. One thing that irks me is the search tool. If I search for a name, why wouldn’t the results be all emails with that person, in some sort of order? I’ve tried to understand the results that would come up but I just got frustrated. I do like that I can sometimes (other times there’s no results when I know that’s not the case) search phrases, though.

title: Badge and Send
text:
The app is amazing overall. Far better than the stock mail app. My two gripes will possibly make me look elsewhere though... 1) The app perpetually states that I have 2 unread emails. I open the app. Nada. All settings are on focus only for notifications. Still nada. Reset phone. Deleted all other emails. Still keep getting the phantom email badge notification. This by itself is enough to delete the app. Will give it a few days to see if there’s an update or it just fixes itself, then moving on. 2) why is there no function to send emails at a later time? Snooze is awesome, but sometimes k just want to schedule send an email.

Update: this still hasn’t been fixed. Basic feature of any email app is a notification that is accurate.

title: Good app, but can we revert back in one area?
text: I use this app all the time for work and generally find it user-friendly and particularly love the calendar and ease of scheduling meetings. One area for a change request: since the last update, when I toggle between an Outlook email/attachment and another app I cannot return to the original email or attachment. Instead it goes to the main inbox page, so I have to search to find the email again. Very frustrating - makes it hard to look up information and reply quickly, particularly if the email isn’t at the top of your inbox. Please change. Makes it hard to use your email as a reference point on an iPhone.

title: Mediocre
text:
The refresh rate on sent, drafts, and new mail is extremely slow. Regardless of my connection strength, whether it be on lte, wifi, etc. it is still around 15 or so minutes for it to update that info. So I’m left wondering if an email actually sent or not. Also, notifications are subpar. It also will not notify me of emails received in the supposed “other” section. Which it decides what emails go in there without my consent to do so. There are issues on here that need addressing.

Edit: 
The notifications on the main mail folder are just as bad! I had a time sensitive email in which I needed to know when I got a reply. It wasn’t until 2 hours later that I noticed I had a reply email. This is a serious issue. I don’t understand how this is never addressed in the sparse updates given.

title: Hey thanks for this avoidable pain I have now
text:
The app refuses to have highlighted dates and times integrate with the main iOS calendar, or whatever you might actually use. Seems like a minor annoyance at first, but live with it for a while and it gets WORSE, not better, because it’s so anti-intuitive for what should be a simple thing. You’ll forget about it, and then you’ll use it thinking it does the NORMAL thing but instead it will be whatever devious thing the app has in store for you.

And it doesn’t control for what account you’re using that well (in the above example, even, which is SUPER fun for invites it surprises you with sending from the wrong account). Nor does it let you customize your sending address. 

But otherwise I really like it. 😑

title: Outlook the only business game in town
text:
I'm using Outlook for my own companies all business related mail. It is the best platform to have trouble free interactions with my clients and customers.

I use it predominantly on my PC but also daily on my iPad and my iPhone.

It is truly seamless on all those platforms.

There are two challenges as part of feedback.

The Outlook related "contacts" completely mess up my iPhone contacts and created 10-12 copies of most contacts when syncing.

This creates a bloated 20,000 contact list that reappears every time I spend days deleting them...  this is a serious drawback.

The other challenge compared to using Outlook on the browser instead of the PC program is that sometimes it needs to "think" and locks up for a good 10-15 seconds in spite of me being the only user on a FTTH with 100Mbps up and down speed.

Google mail never does that and even Outlook on a browser seems faster.  The program is doing something that takes forever several times per day.

All the best,

Per

title: “Read more” a constant irritation
text:
I get a number of newsletters, news briefs, and other longish emails.  Unlike the desktop Outlook, the iPad version often loads only part of the email, and decides arbitrarily to put a “read more” link before the full download.  I have to click this link and start from the beginning to get to the remainder of the email.  Is there some reason Outlook wants to pester me to complete this gratuitous operation?  Why not just load the whole email?  If, unlikely as it seems, there is a reason, why not provide a switch to turn it off?

Otherwise, good app, although desktop version is more useful.

title: Unreliable
text:
I’m so sick of having to go to my junk mail-or worse the deleted box-to save emails that should have gone to my inbox. Emails from addresses that are very common to me-opened, read, and responded to all the time-are sent directly to the junk and DELETED boxes. Info don’t go searching for stuff on a regular basis, I’d be missing crazy important emails all the time. I’m talking about mail from the addresses of  friends’ and relatives’ who I’ve been emailing for years, responses from emails that I’ve sent, addresses that I’ve already marked as “safe”…you name it. 
This is an an awful app, very unreliable and very difficult to use. Just about all settings have to be made from a computer because the app won’t do it. 
Find another email app. Don’t use this one.

title: Used to be great.
text: Since iOS 13, Outlook has lost it’s ability to stay open in the background. Almost every time I switch back to it, it re-launches the app from “scratch”, losing any searches or specific emails I may have had open. This holds true on my iPad Pro and iPhone 11 Pro. Super frustrating! Has been my go-to email/calendar app for years and I’ve stuck with it for months thinking Microsoft would figure it out or that it was Apple’s fault. After multiple iOS updates and several Outlook app updates, it still does it almost every time. Terrible!

title: By far my favorite Mail app for iOS!
text:
There are so many great features in this app they help me stay productive! The ability to move promotions and emails by annoying clients to another’s folder is spectacular!

I have long been a user of Yahoo! Mail, Gmail and the native (uninspired) ios mail Addition to various email applications, but this is my favorite by far!

The outlook mail is unique in that it gives a high degree of customer customization such a signature use archive and collection. 

Although I would not use this application for all my email particularly when I’m looking at working with a freelance client, I enjoy using this email to browse through promotions, my school work, and my personal notifications.

Some features I would prefer to see in this app would include stacking emails, and sending emails which is only seems to be available in native apps, and a better way to organize contacts Rather than giving a long list. 

However, this app is my new go to app for most of my emails!

title: A great email app... better than Gmail mobile
text: I’ve been using this email app on iOS for several years now— with two gmail addresses and now with my work Outlook address. It’s great... seamless and with better UX than the native gmail iOS app itself. The integrated calendar together in one app is essential and still something google has not caught on to. The snooze feature is amazing and not even available on outlook for Mac desktop. The only thing still needing improvement is the search functionality... but by and large this is the best MS product I use... and I love Mac and Google.

title: Almost there..
text:
Outlook is great for sending and receiving emails while on the go in addition to keeping current with your calendar. One main feature I miss everyday however is being able to see my tasks for the day as it makes it difficult to plan appointments if you are not in front of your desktop. Another feature I missed at first was notes but I have been able to see my notes recently using OneNote so although it’s other app, I can live with it.
Last but not least is that outlook on iOS doesn’t give me the option of scheduling a Skype/teams meeting from outlook so this continues to be one of the things I can only do from my desktop.

title: Great, but recently changed for the worse
text: I used to think that this app was perfect. It allowed me to manage multiple emails easily, and it has a sleek design. However, recently in the last week or so, the focused email suddenly changed. I have notifications set where it only notifies me with focused emails. Before, it worked flawlessly, alerting me about important emails and ignoring the unimportant ones. Recently, that all changed. Now, emails from advertising and mailing lists are bombarding me with messages and notifications as they are now showing up in the focused section. Because of this unwanted change, I am now considering changing to another email app. It was great while it lasted.

title: Cross platform is awful
text: I’ve been forced to use Outlook for work for years now, and the lack of ability to actually see emails from months ago on mobile (still very relevant/important mail), even when searching for exact phrases that I know exist on desktop, and even when searching within defined folders of my account, the app says there’s no more matches, and it makes me useless unless I’m at my desktop at work. I have had to defer action on critical aspects of my job, solely because I can’t access my actual email string that was started on desktop. I’ve updated my phone and app repeatedly hoping it’d solve the problem, but apparently Outlook has stood fast in their reasoning that anything older than a month can no longer be important and you shouldn’t be allowed to see it anymore

title: Worst email app!
text: I have AOL as my email provider and it was very difficult to set up the Outlook app. I contacted CS twice. First time, they gave my incomplete instructions on how to login to the app. I figured out most of it on my own but I was still receiving an error message. I sent a screenshot of the message and was immediately disconnected from chat. So I contacted chat again giving the same information and still haven’t received any help. Thankfully Google helped. So now I have my account active and am trying to get my emails from my AOL account. Been waiting for 30 minutes while the message still saying “updating”. In the meantime, I added my Gmail account and had zero issues. This app is a complete waste of time. I understand that AOL is an outdated email provider so maybe Microsoft should advise people before they download the app that it doesn’t work for AOL.

title: Great UI but issues with fundamentals
text: I really like a lot of the Outlook app. I like that my mail and calendar are in the same app. I like the way emails are grouped. I like the way I can easily swap between accounts.  However, none of that matters if e-mails are delayed when either sending or receiving them. I’ve also had an issue with emails sitting in my outbox and never actually being sent. I’ve had a dozen emails received hours late as well and some of them are time sensitive. In addition, aggregate emails from services like google groups are basically impossible to read. I’ve had enough issues with the fundamentals that I have to move back to the gmail app, which I’m not in love with. I’m still frustrated that the Inbox app was killed, but I need to send and receive my emails on a timely basis.

title: Text editing quit working
text: At some point in recent history, text editing has quit working and it’s been inconvenient enough that I quit using Outlook. I still have it installed and keep checking for updates but if I type text and then double-tap to select that text, when I continue typing, that selected text should be overwritten, like every other app on my phone, but in Outlook, now that text is just inserted next to the selected text. I’ve checked for Accessibility settings thinking something was just off but no go. Please fix this, or tell me how.

title: Solid but not stellar
text: My personal favorite for email is Spark even though it isn’t perfect. My biggest gripes about Outlook (and other Microsoft apps) is they haven’t fully built out the enterprise lockdown capabilities so I can still do stuff on my personal account. For example, I have both my work email and personal email accounts in the Outlook app. Totally understand that I can’t copy/paste info from my work email into other apps outside the Microsoft ecosystem to keep company data secure. However, it also prevents me from copy/pasting from my personal email to other apps. This is a real pain and not the way it should work. Outlook should know the difference between sources and behave appropriately.

title: User Friendly & Smooth
text:
I’ve used many email apps and clients on both phones and computers. This is one of the more user friendly apps I’ve encountered. Dark mode is always a plus for me. This app is also very responsive and doesn’t lag at all. I have an iPhone 11 and it’s been one of the smoothest running email apps I’ve used, including the mail client built into the iPhone. Also is user friendly in terms of customization. I uploaded my company logo as my email signature. All the setting are easy to figure out and work great as well.

10/10 would recommend.

title: I've emailed since email became a thing!
text: I remember years ago, I had a mid level position in a fairly large company.  No one (owners, Exec's...) had an e-mail address on their business card yet.  I "think" I may have been the first!!  I just added it and it was almost odd at the time!  It was a smaller company named after a city in Alaska.  Dial up I think!  Was there anything else!?  It made me stand out.  Since then the progression to the current Outlook has been an adventure.  It's so awesome now!  Clear, clean, and efficient.  I'm really enjoying Outlook and how easy it makes it all for me.  Great job!!

title: Almost perfect mail app
text:
So I like this app very much. So much that I uninstalled iOS Mail app and doing business only from this app. I have 9 mail accounts and 2 shared e-mail boxes set up. Works perfectly.

I just need one more feature - delete and load next unread. Let me be more precise. I would like to go into specific e-mail and then delete this e-mail after this is done app would load next e-mail or next unread e-mail (option would be nice - also directionality would be nice to set up - older/newer). By doing this I don’t need to click to enter another e-mail (as per my preference). It saves me a click each time - think 30-50 clicks daily.

Otherwise excellent app

title: I can’t see any of my sent messages !
text:
UPDATE: I just wrote this and somehow they never published my 1 star review ?!!! 

The app looks nice and all BUT I can’t see any of my sent emails!!. I’ve been emailing costumers all day and I can’t find a sent folder nor can’t create one. I can’t keep track of which email I’ve answered because for some reason they did not have this automatic función of saving send emails ?! What year is this ?? This needs be a built in feature! I wasted 1 hour looking at blogs online to see how I can set it up but nothing works. I’ve emailed myself from one account to my gmail account and gmail makes it so easy for me to see the whole thread / conversation. I have to use this because my company used outlook unfortunately. But God this has been a headache. I personally use gmail and it’s so much easier to manage.

Really hate this app. Worst app ever.

title: User feedback ignored for two years, no option for traditional reply and reply all buttons.
text:
The Outlook team has flatly ignored the overwhelming UserVoice feedback from the community for over two years that some people still prefer to triage email with traditional Reply and Reply All buttons, rather than an inline compose experience.  In fact, they continually try to bury the feedback - at one point just deleting the entire feedback item on UserVoice to make it go away rather than actually resolving it.

No integrity from the program management team, and no care for the end user experience - you’re better off sticking with the built in Apple Mail client.  I reverted back when the change was made over two years ago, and I found I haven’t missed Outlook;  the Apple mail client is now good enough to use on a daily basis.  I recommend you do the same.

title: Notifications completely messed up on iOS 11
text:
I don’t know if this is Apple’s fault or the fact that the developers haven’t updated the app to take advantage of the new notifications system that Apple has foisted upon us, but the lock screen notifications are broken. 

When you delete the notification or mark as read from the lock screen, it asks for your password. After entering the password, it should automatically finish the action you’ve selected. Instead, after you’ve entered the password, it takes you back to the lock screen where the action you tried to do hasn’t taken place. So you have to repeat it (mark as read/delete etc). 

I submitted this feedback as well a few months ago but still no response from developers. Please fix this.

title: Horrible App!!!
text: I'm forced to use this for work, but I can't count the number of times it has failed me and other coworkers repeatedly!!! How in the world did it get any positive reviews??? I primarily work at various locations without computer access so I mostly work from my phone.  Maybe the experience is different in an office with a computer, but I can't create group lists to send mass emails, my attachments in forwards don't always go through, and if the recipient is in a location with bad service, they might recieve no email at all from me despite my side showing no error messages or such, leading me to believe my email went through.  I hate this app and wouldn't use it at all except my company requires it.  I've never had this level of difficulty with Gmail; Gmail is by far more reliable.

title: Great App - a few things I’m still looking for
text: Like most people here, looking for a way that the signature would be the same whether I’m on my iPad/iPhone vs my desktop. Also when you reply to someone it only uses a Times New Roman. I just wish the experience of my emails was the same across the apps. But I really prefer using this for my work email over the Apple Mail - the contact integration is much for friendly and you can look up emails from a specific person easier. The experience is pretty much the same (other than the two issues listed) from my desktop app which I enjoy.

title: Love the app, don’t like the sent from tag
text:
The app is amazing! I love how integrated it is with my work email and the ease of use is amazing and I love the GUI interface. However, the only draw back is when I am replying to customers or other business professionals it leaves a tag of where it was sent from. Wish there was an option to turn it off, I don’t necessarily want other to know what device I am writing an email from. Sometimes, when that tag is added it gives room to assume you are immediately available and that may not be the case. Hope this feedback is valuable. 

Best Regards,
Valued Customer

title: Absolute perfection.
text: This app has come a long way over the years. FLAWLESSLY integrates my work and personal mail and calendars. Legit the ONLY mail app I’ve found that seamlessly combines MS Exchange and Google accounts into one seamless experience. The mail, the calendars, the widgets; absolute perfection. This app actually improves my quality of life. I no longer need to switch back and forth between multiple apps to get native functionality for each. This app does it all. Microsoft: take the developers of this app out for a lobster dinner. They’ve earned it. Incredible app; a truly best in class product.

title: Great App!
text: After trying out many different Email clients and then sticking to the default Apple Mail app, I decided to try Outlook due to the excellent reviews everywhere. I must say that the reviews were totally right. This is an email client with the most intuitive experience and makes managing Email very easy. In some ways, it is even better than the Gmail app for handling Email. One of the best things is the custom swipe action. I wish there was a way to flag emails and have them appear in the Focused inbox, but other than that, this is one Email client that satisfies all my needs. 👍 to the Microsoft team for such a great app.

title: I like it, but...
text:
Everything works pretty well, except - I can’t seem to format my ‘signature’ properly in the ‘settings’.  I am unable to use ‘bold’ (or italic/underline) and the formatting keeps shifting - I have ‘new lines/spaces’ that disappear or appear when I write emails (such as have an empty line appear in my address), when the default signature is used. It makes my emails look a little amateur, and now I have to manually fix it each time. 

Second big issue is when I get invitations in my calendar they are automatically added, so now I don’t see I have new calendar items, and I have no control when initial receiving an invitation, to accept or reject. It just magically appears in my calendar, whether I have a conflict, or not.

title: Don’t Call It Outlook
text: I downloaded and started using this app because it was called MS Outlook, thinking that it would mimic the functionality that I have from Outlook 365 on my Windows 10 PC.  I am very disappointed with this apps functionality, particularly with the management of contact information.  There is no direct access to an address book.  There is no easy way to create a new contact or edit an existing contact.  There is no way to create mailing lists or groups and there is no way link iOS Contacts with the ones I already have on my iPhone/iPad or with my Outlook 365 contacts.  There are other shortcomings with this app, but there are too many to list here.

title: Removing Functionality why?
text: This was a solid 4 4.5 star app for my Exchange connected office accounts. Then they went and boned up the Archive function by not letting me select a folder besides Archive any more. Come on Microsoft! I archive based on year and want those emails to go into the specific year folder. That was one of the reasons I was happy to switch from Apple Mail for work but now the only advantage this gives me is my work email is in a different app. It is bad enough when you don’t provide a real change log with your app’a updates but removing functionality without notice is crap. Bring it back.

title: Great app - until now
text: I’ve been using this app for a few years now and it’s been awesome. I love the focused inbox and the calendar being in one app instead of a whole different one. The last two weeks have been hell. I have three accounts logged in - all three are G-suite emails. Each one has asked multiple times a day over the past two weeks to authenticate my credentials. Over and over again. I tried deleting one account and now it won’t let me login to that account again. At first I thought it was just one my company’s end. But three accounts from three separate domains seems unlikely. I’d love to use it again if the problem can be fixed.

title: Good for managing multiple emails
text:
I use outlook to keep track of my personal, professional and student email. Before this I used to forward my emails to my personal email but it would cause confusion when replying to emails. This app helps me make sure I’m replying from whatever email I need to without even thinking about it. 

One thing that needs improvement though is attachments. Sometimes things are missing from my Expedia emails and I have to open it up from the source email app for example gmail. other than that it’s great overall.

title: App now stinks. Was "Awesome App!"
text:
Update:  the recent changes to how you interact with mail - how you forward mails, view and navigate a thread, and share content with other apps is broken.  Many tasks that used to be easy are now impossible or at least more difficult.  Example:  I used to be able to print an individual email. I can't now. I used to be able to send an email to Evernote by using the share button, but that button is no more.  I used to be able to collapse a message in a thread. No more...  the only reason I am keeping this app now is because the calendar is great.  One star...

Old review:  I love this app. So easy to deal with attachments. Great integration with Dropbox. Mail, Calendar, and files work great. Simple and straight forward.  This app brings a smile to my face!  It has a few quirks, but in general it just works!  Love it!

title: It Zooms
text:
The main reason I started using Outlook (as opposed to the built in mail program) is that it allows me to zoom in on messages. As my eyes have changed, I’m becoming very sensitive to emails sent in small fonts — especially those that override the iPad defaults and got tired of disregarding them for that idiocy. 

Outlook gives you a zoom button that hides the list of emails and zooms up the content of the one you’re looking at. At that point, you can pinch and open the mail and zoom in by whatever degree you prefer. Now why didn’t Apple think of that.

title: Good for O365 users
text: Outlook mobile is a decent iOS email app.  I’ve tried a number of different apps.  We are O365 users at my company and it’s a nice seamless integration between the desktop version and the mobile tool (drafts, folders, etc).  The attachment feature is the best I’ve seen, particularly if you use OneDrive.  My two complaints are the inability to write rich text and use of images/html signatures, something that the native Apple app allows. The feature request has been denied by the development team so I wouldn’t expect this to change. This would be a 5 star rating if the signature feature changes.
